name: Ark of the Covenant
shortDescription: Sacred gold-covered chest containing the Tablets of the Law, the holiest object in ancient Israel
fullDescription: The Ark of the Covenant (Hebrew: ◊ê◊®◊ï◊ü ◊î◊ë◊®◊ô◊™ Aron HaBrit) is the most sacred object in Jewish tradition, a gold-covered wooden chest that housed the Tablets of the Law given to Moses at Mount Sinai. Constructed according to God's precise instructions, the Ark resided in the Holy of Holies, first in the Tabernacle and later in Solomon's Temple. It served as the throne of God's earthly presence (Shekhinah) and symbolized the covenant between God and Israel. The Ark was carried before the Israelites during their wilderness wanderings and in battle, demonstrating God's protective presence. Its fate after the First Temple's destruction remains one of Judaism's greatest mysteries.

mythologyContexts.usage: The Ark served as the focal point of Israelite worship, housing the covenant tablets and manifesting God's presence among His people. It was carried into battle, crossed the Jordan River, and resided in the Holy of Holies where the High Priest entered once yearly on Yom Kippur.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Ark represents the covenant between God and Israel, the divine presence dwelling among humanity, and the throne of the invisible God. The cherubim symbolize angelic guardians of holiness. The acacia wood represents incorruptibility, while the gold overlay symbolizes divine glory and royalty. The Ark carrying the broken tablets alongside the whole ones teaches that even broken vessels retain sanctity. The space between the cherubim, where God spoke to Moses, represents the intersection of heaven and earth, the meeting point of divine and human.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The Ark remains Judaism's most sacred lost treasure, with numerous traditions about its hiding place. It symbolizes the lost glory of the Temple era and messianic hope for restoration. The modern Torah Ark (Aron Kodesh) in synagogues is named after the original and serves a similar function of housing sacred scrolls. The mystery of the Ark's location has inspired countless legends, searches, and fictional accounts. Kabbalistic tradition sees the Ark as corresponding to the Sefirah of Malkhut, representing divine sovereignty manifested in the physical world.
